instruction: What metric was chosen and how far can this metric go for rapid detection of low concentrations of harmful cyanobacterial species (HCBs) within dense populations of spirulina cultures in microalgal bioreactors?
Output: The metric chosen in the study is Low-Resolution Raman Spectroscopy (LRRS). LRRS was used as a tool for rapid detection of low concentrations of harmful cyanobacterial species (HCBs) within dense populations of spirulina (Arthrospira platensis) cultures. The study demonstrated that LRRS can detect and quantify algal and cyanobacterial species at concentrations as low as 10(3) cells/mL and can robustly discriminate between species at concentrations of 10(4) cells/mL. Additionally, LRRS and chemometric analyses were able to detect the presence of low concentrations (10(3) cells/mL) of contaminating species, including the toxic cyanobacterium Microcystis aeruginosa, within dense spirulina cultures. Therefore, the chosen metric of LRRS has the capability to detect and quantify HCBs and other contaminant species in microalgal bioreactors, potentially enabling real-time detection and early warning of harmful algal blooms in aquatic ecosystems.
